reviewText:
If you love micro transactions, download this game. If you don't...then stay away. Even as a free game I rated it down due to the micro-transactions and energy system which really annoys me with these types of games. This game does have great parts but it is clearly following the mobile and facebook micro-transaction games that require you to wait time before you can do more levels or pay to get more energy or pay to buy items and unlocks. Now that isn't necessarily a bad thing if you are on a mobile platform or on facebook but I just feel that these sorts of games should be as far away from Steam as possible.

As a game, the graphics are great, the drawings and icons and world map and all the graphical elements are done really well, I do have to hand it to the devs who made this game for that. The storyline scenes at the start however are so low res you can see the pixels and how faded it looks due to the upscale of the video. Very poorly done.

There are some great puzzles in the game though especially when opening chests and having to connect the coloured dots. That is quite fun but time limited. I think overall it's a game that will appeal to those who are used to micro-transactions, and I'd enjoy this more if it didn't shove the desire to purchase at my face every two minutes. In addition, I cannot stand any game that has energy and stops you from playing and having to wait or pay for it to refill to continue. Games are meant to be played, not spent waiting until you can play it.

reviewText:
Recommended with some caveats. This is a Mahjong game within a time management/puzzle type game.  You play a round of Mahjong to obtain items, gold and power-ups. You use the items to combine and reach a goal, which gets you more gold and power-ups. Yes...it is also a game with micro-transactions where you can buy extras that you aren't able to get. If you're a ♥♥♥♥-poor Mahjong player and/or want to play for hours at a time, then you'll probably have to spend money because you'll run out of energy. Normally, however, if you play about an hour or so and then return the next day, all your energy is restored and you can build up gold and gems to purchase incidentals without having to lay out actual hard cash. Also, every day there is a new bonus; it encourages to boot up the game on a daily basis. There are also puzzles to figure out to open chests where you can get more items. And leveling up gets you access to more places.

I also like the natural sounds of birds, crickets, etc in the background along with light flute-like music.

Personally, so far, I like it. It's different. And, hello, it's free. It's ridiculous to complain about the micro-transactions aspect when you're not having to pay for the game and purchases are not required unless you're impatient. If it gets to a point where it becomes too annoying, I'll just delete it. Mahjong games are common place.

I give it a 4 out of 5.

reviewText:
A superb Mahjong game that is both challenging and fun, with 10 different Mahjong boards per location, and it even comes with achievements.

First, let us start with the usual and biggest Steam community complaint: micro-transactions.  Though this game has micro-transactions the player NEVER, EVER has to buy anything so this IS NOT a pay to win game.  The player can, of course, spend money for crystals and coins if they chose.  Remember this is a coffee break or lunch break game, meant to be played in 15-20 minute increments over days, weeks, possibly months depending on one's dedication or committment to the game.  This game can not be played to conclusion in one sitting.

This particular game Lost Lands: Mahjong (LL: M)  has the exact same storyline and pretty much the same achievements as Lost Lands: A Hidden Object Adventure (LL: HO).  However, the developers have taken to heart all the comments, compliants and suggestions offered about Lost Lands: HO and improved the overall gameplay of Lost Lands: Mahjong immensely.

First of all, steam achievements are earned at the first in-game achievement level up instead of the last as in LL: HO so LL: M is not the grind LL: HO is.  Secondly, the amount needed to level up has been adjusted to fit the achievement such as needing an immense amount of coins to earn that achievement versus earning a location and critter achievement which only requires a very small amount play or items.  10 stars per location and 10 weapons per critter to be exact.  (Just a note:  The coin achievement is very high, and seemingly impossible, however remember there are 15 locations and a player needs a rank of 21 to open the final locations.  Trust me the coins needed to level up that achievement will eventually come just through game play, just as night mode and silhouette mode achievements will come through play.)  Third, the utterly useless achievement UNLUCKY found in LL: HO (not being able complete the scene within the time limit) will probably be one of the first achievements anyone earns in LL: M considering the challenge some Mahjong boards present.  (Any board that runs out of moves is considered eligible for the count on the UNLUCKY achievement.)

I definitely recommend this Mahjong game for just the amount of Mahjong boards that eventually can be played (10 per location x 15 locations = 150 Mahjong boards total.)  As far as achievements go (for those that care) I will probably have all these achievements before LL: HO (lololol)
